Facebook Twitter Google + Email Print The life and death of the carbon tax By Bernie Becker 04/05/17 10:00 AM EDT CARBON TAX, WE HARDLY KNEW YE: The Trump administration quashed the idea that it had any interest in a carbon tax or a value-added tax on Tuesday, following a Washington Post report that the White House was looking into those options. There already had been some chatter about the administration’s potential interest in those two policies, but a carbon tax and a VAT would have faced a lot of opposition among Republicans. The words Mitch McConnell and carbon tax really don’t mix, for instance, and House Ways and Means Chairman Kevin Brady noted on CNBC that “both the House and Senate in recent years have weighed in pretty heavily with resistance against those ideas.” (House Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows said as much to our Colin Wilhelm about a VAT.) Story Continued Below But a couple of downtown types told Morning Tax that it’s pretty natural for a new administration, especially one with relatively little D.C. experience, to kick the tires on those sorts of ideas. Senate Finance Chairman Orrin Hatch had that sort of thought as well, per the Washington Examiner’s Joseph Lawler. Still, you could probably be forgiven for thinking that President Donald Trump’s allies want his administration to whip itself into shape a little more on taxes, especially after senior officials said taxes would be an easier job than health care. “At this point I'm just assuming all of these silly rumors are meaningless. He's already got a good business tax plan that I and others helped write. Stephen Miller agrees with it, [Steven] Mnuchin agrees with it and [Steve] Bannon agrees with it. Make it simple and pass what you've got,” CNBC’s Larry Kudlow told POLITICO's Morning Money, referencing Trump’s senior policy adviser, Treasury secretary and chief strategist, respectively. For his part, Brady, asked about the lack of one person in charge of tax within the Trump administration, would only tell Colin “they have a very talented team” and “they'll have to decide who's running point for them.” IT’S WEDNESDAY — and, in a forerunner to today’s budget battles, the 95th birthday of the American Birth Control League (which eventually became Planned Parenthood) and the 84th birthday of the Civilian Conservation Corps (which became the model for an AmeriCorps program). Let us know what’s going on out there. Email: bbecker@politico.com, teckert@politico.com, bfaler@politico.com, cwilhelm@politico.com, alorenzo@politico.com. Twitter: @berniebecker3, @tobyeckert, @brian_faler, @colinwilhelm, @AaronELorenzo, @POLITICOPro and @Morning_Tax. THE DAY IN DBCFT: The House Agriculture Committee is wading into the tax reform debate this morning — and both sides of the border adjustment fight seem to believe that the agriculture sector is a key battleground. The short version as to why: The House GOP’s destination-based cash flow tax is meant to help export-heavy sectors like agriculture. Industry advocates and agriculture state lawmakers understand that, but also openly worry about potential retaliation from trading partners. With that in mind, the American Made Coalition — the organization backing the House plan — has a new statement on the topic from Blue Diamond Growers, the California company known for almonds that’s a part of the group. “Agriculture faces unique challenges and a complicated tax code is one of them. Blue Diamond Growers supports modernizing our tax code and creating a system that is fair and promotes economic growth. The House blueprint offers an opportunity to achieve these outcomes,” said Bronte Wigen, a representative for the company. The pro coalition also has a new web video, showcasing border adjustability’s fans among the economist set — featuring, among others, Martin Feldstein of Harvard and Doug Holtz-Eakin of the American Action Forum. On the anti side, Americans for Affordable Products has a release detailing all the pro-agriculture people and companies skeptical of a border adjustment — like former Senate Finance Chairman Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), Sens. Cory Gardner (R-Colo.) and Mike Rounds (R-S.D.), and John Deere’s chief executive. Also of note: It’s no secret that there’s not a lot of support — or maybe none at all — for a border adjustment in the Senate. But as POLITICO's Heather Caygle and Josh Dawsey reported, Marc Short, Trump’s point man on the Hill, told a group of more centrist Democrats that the idea was “dead on arrival in the Senate,” as one congressman put it. MAYBE NOT DISTRUST, BUT CERTAINLY VERIFY: Brady kicked off his outreach to Democrats on tax reform on Tuesday, with perhaps the most sympathetic audience possible — the more business-friendly New Democrats. But as our Aaron Lorenzo and your Morning Tax author found, the New Dems are far from sold on what Brady’s offering, and the familiar obstacles to a bipartisan tax deal — like should a tax overhaul raise revenue — haven’t gone anywhere. “No one said: ‘Love it. You got me.’ No one said that. But if there’s going to be a friendly audience open to tax reform a la Dave Camp, it’s going to be New Dems,” said Rep. Gerry Connolly of Virginia, the New Dems’ whip, referring to the former Republican Ways and Means chairman. “But we’re far away from embracing the specifics. Far away.” THAT COULD LEAVE A MARK: Long story short — IRS structuring investigations led to the seizure of legally obtained assets around nine out of 10 times between 2012 and 2014, according to a new report from Treasury’s inspector general for tax administration. That’s in large part because Justice Department officials wanted quick resolutions, not necessarily thorough investigations, our Toby Eckert reports. The IRS changed its processes after news reports questioned its seizure policies, but Reps. Peter Roskam (R-Ill.) and Joe Crowley (D-N.Y.) are still pushing legislation to further protect taxpayers from the investigations. Roskam and other Republicans said in a statement Tuesday that the audit confirmed that the agency had been abusing its authority. Meanwhile, Nina Olson, the national taxpayer advocate — pardon the pun here — seized on a somewhat under-the-radar issue within the report. In short, Olson is worried that the IRS will only take into account a person’s constitutional rights in a seizure investigation, and not their taxpayer rights, such as the right to challenge a position held by the agency. That’s even though Congress codified the taxpayer bill of rights in 2015. Also of note on the IRS front: The agency announced today that it would begin sending letters within weeks to the taxpayers who have debts that will be handled by private collectors, as your Morning Tax author noted. The IRS said it would carefully watch to see if scammers saw the private collection program, passed by Congress in 2015, as an opportunity to expand their enterprises. And for your regular reminder: Grassley and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-N.Y.) have been longtime fans of that kind of program, even though Olson has said two previous attempts were failures. (Two of the four debt collectors in the program are in New York, and one is in Iowa.) TRY, TRY AGAIN: Sens. Jeanne Shaheen (D-N.H.) and Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) are out with a new bill that would mandate that the IRS give many taxpayers a simple return — one page, with the information already filled in. Some European countries already offer that service, and Warren, Shaheen and other senators rolled out a similar measure last year. But the tax prep industry here in the U.S. isn’t so enamored with the proposal, as ProPublica noted, and some Republicans have questioned giving the IRS the dual job of preparer and collector. KA. CHING. Rep. Kristi Noem (R-S.D.) is running to become Gov. Kristi Noem — and she’s leaning fully on her seat on the House Ways and Means Committee to help her get there, as Campaign Pro’s Daniel Strauss reported. Noem has filed to run for both governor and Congress again, but her team says she’s all in to be South Dakota’s chief executive. She’s also been hosting a fair number of events with her fellow Ways and Means Republicans — luckily, right as tax reform and health care are heating up. (Stay for the cameo from Cleta Mitchell, the lawyer who represented tea party groups suing the IRS.) THE WORLD ACCORDING TO DIMON: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, is out pounding the pavement for tax reform in his annual letter to shareholders, making the case that America’s high statutory corporate rate is dragging down wages for workers. Dimon also reiterated his support for expanding the Earned Income Tax Credit, which is aimed at boosting the working poor and which he says helps bring people back into the workforce. (Or as the Business Insider headline put it: “Jamie Dimon just doubled down in supporting a little-known tax that pays poor people.”) INTERNATIONAL UPDATE — ITALY, VATICAN, REUNITED: Italy on Tuesday put the Vatican on a list of countries with cooperative financial sectors — after years on the outside, Reuters reported. Pope Francis has made a point of saying he wants to clean up the Vatican’s banking industry — after, as Reuters put it, financial organizations had “criticized the Vatican for providing a tax haven for well-connected Italians by allowing them to hold accounts in the Vatican bank, formally known as the Institute for Works of Religion (IOR).” STATE NEWS — KEEP PASSING THE SALT: Seven groups representing state and local governments are out with a new letter backing the state and local tax deduction, which would almost certainly get a close look in any GOP tax overhaul. (The groups also want to keep the exemption for municipal bond interest, also key to local governments.) “We do not believe it is the intent of Congress to undermine the ability of states and local governments to meet the needs of the citizens we all serve through comprehensive tax reform,” the groups wrote. Speaking of SALT: The Los Angeles Times examines the condition of the deduction, a big deal for California. THINK D.C. IS DOING TOO WELL? Then you’ve got some new ammunition from Mayor Muriel Bowser’s latest budget — which projects that revenues will grow another $300 million in the upcoming fiscal year, The Washington Post reports. The budget would also continue to implement tax cuts enacted by the city council in 2014, though critics say Bowser’s latest proposals don’t do enough to strengthen the safety net. That said, lower- and middle-income families can expect to pay less in taxes because of more robust personal exemptions and standard deductions. QUICK LINKS — Former White House Council of Economic Advisers Chairman Jason Furman’s prescriptions for making tax reform bipartisan. — Democrats prepare another go for Trump’s tax returns. — Small-business owners protest a potential soda tax in Seattle. DID YOU KNOW? The Vatican features banks with ATMs that use Latin. « View Archives Authors: Bernie Becker bbecker@politico.com About The Author Bernie Becker is a tax reporter for POLITICO Pro, where he is primarily responsible for writing the Morning Tax tipsheet. He previously covered taxes for The Hill, and was an editorial assistant for The New York Times in Washington. A native of Martinsville, Va., Becker has degrees from the College of William and Mary and the University of Maryland. He now lives in Northwest D.C. with his wife and young daughter. His hobbies include running, reading history books, eating spicy food and watching his daughter chase his cat. (AHGP) to Hold Korn/Ferry International (KFY) Getting Very Positive Press Coverage, Analysis Shows Teachers Advisors LLC Raises Position in AFLAC Incorporated (AFL) April 5th, 2017 - 0 comments - Filed Under - by Stacy Sanders Filed Under: Finance - SEC Filing Articles Tweet Teachers Advisors LLC raised its position in shares of AFLAC Incorporated (NYSE:AFL) by 0.3% during the fourth quarter, according to its most recent disclosure with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The fund owned 794,930 shares of the company’s stock after buying an additional 2,226 shares during the period. Teachers Advisors LLC’s holdings in AFLAC were worth $55,327,000 as of its most recent SEC filing. Several other institutional investors have also made changes to their positions in AFL. Pegasus Partners Ltd. increased its position in shares of AFLAC by 16.4% in the fourth quarter. Finally, Sowell Financial Services LLC acquired a new position in shares of AFLAC during the fourth quarter worth approximately $265,000. Institutional investors own 62.45% of the company’s stock. AFLAC Incorporated (NYSE:AFL) opened at 72.61 on Wednesday. The firm has a 50-day moving average price of $71.97 and a 200-day moving average price of $70.80. AFLAC Incorporated has a 12-month low of $62.59 and a 12-month high of $74.50. The company has a market cap of $29.15 billion, a P/E ratio of 11.31 and a beta of 1.01. AFLAC (NYSE:AFL) last announced its earnings results on Tuesday, January 31st. The company reported $1.46 EPS for the quarter, missing the Zacks’ consensus estimate of $1.63 by $0.17. The company earned $6 billion during the quarter, compared to analysts’ expectations of $5.65 billion. AFLAC had a return on equity of 13.10% and a net margin of 11.79%. AFLAC’s revenue for the quarter was up 12.7% compared to the same quarter last year. During the same quarter last year, the firm posted $1.56 EPS. On average, equities research analysts forecast that AFLAC Incorporated will post $6.41 earnings per share for the current fiscal year. The Company is involved in supplemental health and life insurance, which is marketed and administered through its subsidiary, American Family Life Assurance Company of Columbus (Aflac). The Company’s insurance business consists of two segments: Aflac Japan and Aflac U.S. Want to see what other hedge funds are holding AFL? Hellenic Shipping Stocks Live International Shipping Stocks Live Commodity Trade Markets Home / Shipping News / International Shipping News / Seadrill in a Free Fall Seen Left to Day Traders as Hope Fades Seadrill in a Free Fall Seen Left to Day Traders as Hope Fades in International Shipping News 05/04/2017 Seadrill Ltd., once the crown jewel of billionaire John Fredriksen’s business empire, is at the mercy of short-term speculators as the biggest funds shun the offshore driller amid a struggle to avoid bankruptcy. “It’s trading at option value and day traders are the ones pushing the price up and down,” Anders Bergland, an analyst at Clarksons Platou Securities AS, said Tuesday, right after the company again warned shareholders and bond investors they were facing steep losses in any restructuring deal. “There are no funds buying this right now, it’s trading.” Seadrill fell as much as 29 percent on Wednesday after closing 38 percent down the day before, already at a record low. The stock traded 25 percent lower at 6.51 kroner as of 12:47 p.m. in Oslo. The company has been working on a restructuring of the offshore-drilling industry’s biggest debt load for more than a year. With net interest-bearing debt of $8.9 billion at the end of 2016, Seadrill has been particularly exposed as oil companies slashed spending following the collapse of crude prices in 2014. ‘Train Wreck’ The risks of equity dilution and bankruptcy had been voiced by the company earlier and should in any case have been “obvious,” said Alex Brooks, an analyst in London at Canaccord Genuity Group Inc. who stopped covering Seadrill last month after following the stock on and off for nearly eight years. “We seem to see this over and over again: shareholders are willing to trade stocks on hope value right up until the moment the train wreck becomes obvious,” he said in an email. “It’s astonishing, and probably reflects rather badly on people like me who are unable to get our message out.” Seadrill has lost 97 percent of its value since the middle of 2014, contributing to a more than 40 percent drop in Fredriksen’s net worth, which is currently estimated by the Bloomberg Billionaire Index at about $9.7 billion. The biggest sellers of the shares last year included Barclays Plc, JPMorgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Deutsche Bank AG, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. The most important market news of the day. Get our markets daily newsletter. The company said on Tuesday it got further extensions on bank loans totaling $2.9 billion, allowing it to again postpone the deadline for a restructuring deal by three months to the end of July. Warning shareholders they faced “minimal recovery” of their positions, Seadrill said a comprehensive agreement with creditors would “likely involve schemes of arrangement or chapter 11 proceedings,” eventualities that had previously been mentioned by the company in case a deal was not reached. Fredriksen, a Norwegian-born Cypriot who acts as Seadrill’s chairman and owns about 24 percent of the company, said last week the company was getting closer to a restructuring agreement, though it was a “big job.” He repeated that in an interview with Dagens Naeringsliv on Tuesday, adding Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection was only one option among others and that how much capital he puts into the company will depend on the solution. Site Map PDF Subscription Register LogIn Site Map PDF Subscription Register LogIn Economy Policies Finance Photo News Thu, April 6, 2017 | 16:08 North Korea Entertainment Music Dramas & TV shows Movies Performances Exhibitions Photo News Opinion Editorial Columnists Park Moo-jong Choi Sung-jin Tong Kim Korean Historical Sense Andrew Salmon John Burton Jason Lim Donald Kirk Kim Ji-myung Jay Kim Andrei Lankov Frank Ching Hyon O'Brien Younghoy Kim Kimaro Michael McManus Deauwand Myers Casey Lartigue, Jr. Bernard Rowan Stephen Costello Semoon Chang Michael Breen Lee Seong-hyon Reporter's Notebook Guest Column Thoughts of the Times Letter to the Editor Times Forum Cartoon Today in History Feature Image of Korea Small Picture Economy Policies Finance Photo News Biz & Tech Automotive IT Heavy industries Light industries Science Game Photo News National Politics Foreign Affairs Embassy News Defense Affairs Foreign Communities Investigations Diseases & welfare Labor & environment Education Seoul & provinces Obituaries Photo News Culture Books Religions Healthcare Food Fortune Telling Hotel & Travel Fashion Korean traditions Trend Photo News Sports Football Baseball Golf Other Sports 2018 PyeongChang Photo News World SCMP Asia Pacific Americas Europe Middle East Africa Community Time Forum Market Place Talk Box Study Plaza Photos Learning English Finance Global financial firms leaving Korea Posted : 2017-04-05 16:59 Updated : 2017-04-05 17:45 By Nam Hyun-woo A growing number of global financial firms have left Korea or have downsized their businesses here possibly because they no longer see the country's market as lucrative, industry sources said Wednesday. The Korean branch of global asset management firm Fidelity International has reportedly decided to put an end to its fund management businesses recently. Many of its employees have already left the company while some others were moved to Fidelity's other regional affiliates in Hong Kong and Singapore. Its sales department would be kept for the sales of the firm's funds products managed directly by Fidelity headquarters. An official at Fidelity International Korea said: "It is true that there is an ongoing debate about the firm's domestic fund management team, but the company has not been informed about further developments related to the issue." The move came after the Korean branch posted losses in the second to fourth quarters last year. According to the Korea Financial Investment Association, it saw 729 million won ($650,000) in losses during the second quarter and the amount increased to 1.4 billion won in the third quarter and 1.52 billion won in the fourth. Other global asset management firms in Korea struggled last year. Lazard Korea Asset Management saw the size of its funds under management decline by 60 percent in 2016 from a year earlier. They have been faltering here for years. After Goldman Sachs withdrew its asset management unit in Korea in 2012, its peers including JPMorgan Asset Management Korea have downsized their workforces to improve their balance sheets. Among the foreign brokerages active here, Deutsche Securities Korea is rumored to be planning an exit. Though the firm is flatly denying the allegation, such rumors are growing possibly due to its poor performance last year. Fear is also growing in the banking sector, where global lenders' Korean branches saw a contraction in their net profits. According to the Financial Supervisory Service, the combined net profit of 37 branches of foreign banks operating in Korea stood at 764.9 billion won in 2016, down 31.8 percent from a year earlier. The disappointing results are attributable to the dropping interest profit, which decreased 26.2 percent last year. Against this backdrop, watchers worry about an exodus of foreign banks' Korean branches. Last October, BBVA shut its branch in Seoul. Earlier in the year, Goldman Sachs gave up its banking license in Korea and Barclays closed its Seoul office. Their exits seemingly stem from not only their aggravated profitability here but also the introduction of BASEL III banking guidelines, which require banks to substantially strengthen their capital ratios. namhw@ktimes.comMore articles by this reporter [Crime Scene] Graduate student used school lab to cook meth Activist sues Korean, Chinese authorities over air pollution Korea Tour Cards flying off shelves Man jailed for hiring thugs to punish daughter's bullies US may deploy Zumwalt stealth destroyer here [Crime Scene] Police arrest man over alleged sexual assault of Japanese tourist in Seoul Illegal 'ghost marriages' still linger in China Japanese envoy becomes laughing stock in Korea Another ex-comfort woman dies Chinese tourists shun Korea over missile battery Foal Eagle exercise Hazy Seoul No sale to Chinese Fine dust blanket Random candidacy Ostensible friends Worries over Taegeukgi Surprise! VX nerve agent used in assassination of Kim: police Dongwha Group Chairman awarded Park's impeachment About Korea Times CEO Message Times History Contents Distribution Media Kit Contact Us Location Privacy Statement Ombudsman Mobile Service PDF Service RSS Service
Financial News News JP Morgan taps Morgan Stanley for top healthcare banker Morgan Stanley's chairman of M&A in Emea is returning to the bank he first joined in 1992 iStockPhoto By Fareed Sahloul April 5, 2017 Updated: 1:23 p.m. GMT JP Morgan has hired rival Morgan Stanley's co-head of healthcare investment banking, according to an internal memo seen by FN. Michele Colocci is rejoining the bank as co-head of of industry coverage for corporates in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, and global co-head of healthcare investment banking. He will share the first of those roles with Harry Hampson and the other with Jeff Stute, according to the memo signed by JP Morgan's head of banking for Emea, Viswas Raghavan. Colocci will report to Raghavan. At Morgan Stanley he was also most recently chairman of M&A in Emea. He began his career at Bain & Co before joining the M&A team at JP Morgan in Europe in 1992, according to the memo. (BMRN) EVP Sells $346,793.50 in Stock The Carlyle Group LP (CG) Receives Average Rating of “Hold” from Brokerages NGL Energy Partners LP (NGL) Given Consensus Recommendation of “Buy” by Analysts April 5th, 2017 - 0 comments - Filed Under - by Tyrone Williams Filed Under: Consensus Rating Articles - Finance Tweet NGL Energy Partners LP (NYSE:NGL) has been given an average rating of “Buy” by the nine research firms that are presently covering the firm. One equities research analyst has rated the stock with a sell recommendation, two have given a hold recommendation and five have given a buy recommendation to the company. The average 12-month target price among brokerages that have issued ratings on the stock in the last year is $20.57. A number of equities analysts recently weighed in on the stock. Zacks Investment Research downgraded shares of NGL Energy Partners from a “hold” rating to a “strong sell” rating in a report on Friday, February 17th. Raymond James Financial, Inc. raised shares of NGL Energy Partners from a “market perform” rating to an “outperform” rating and set a $24.00 price target on the stock in a report on Thursday, January 12th. FBR & Co cut their price target on shares of NGL Energy Partners from $29.00 to $28.00 and set an “outperform” rating on the stock in a report on Wednesday, February 15th. Stifel Nicolaus downgraded shares of NGL Energy Partners from a “buy” rating to a “hold” rating and cut their price target for the stock from $22.00 to $21.00 in a report on Wednesday, February 8th. Finally, TheStreet raised shares of NGL Energy Partners from a “d+” rating to a “c-” rating in a report on Thursday, January 19th. NGL Energy Partners had a positive return on equity of 9.99% and a negative net margin of 0.85%. The firm earned $3.41 billion during the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $3.09 billion. About NGL Energy Partners NGL Energy Partners LP owns and operates a vertically integrated energy business. The Company’s segments are crude oil logistics, water solutions, liquids, retail propane, refined products and renewables, and corporate and other. Its crude oil logistics segment includes owned and leased crude oil storage terminals, and owned and leased pipeline injection stations.
